TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: told by Giłgiław of Vałulu village

S.FORM: malada nu aya, maretimałimałi a tsemas niamadju.
malada no aya, maretimaljimalji a cemas niamadjo.
S.TRANSL: When we speak of shamans, they have various gods.

S.FORM: łakua tjara tadjaladjalan a sidjapesan a sikapalisian a pagału.
ljakoa tjara tadjaladjalan a sidjapesan a sikapalisian a pagaljo.
S.TRANSL: But they are all more or less the same in their blowing (and) rituals.

S.FORM: aitsu a malada nu izua saqetju djapesen niamadju.
aico a malada no izoa saqetjo djapesen niamadjo.
S.TRANSL: When someone is in pain the shamans blow on them.

S.FORM: nu selapay sitjetsemas niamadju a malada, sa djaułan tua salasaladj niamadju, sana kapalisilisi niamadju.
no selapay sitjecemas niamadjo a malada, sa djaoljan toa salasaladj niamadjo, sana kapalisilisi niamadjo.
S.TRANSL: If it’s a severe case the shamans go into a trance for them and summon their spirit companions and perform rites.

S.FORM: qau nu palisi tiamadju, venay itjen tua tjinutsauan.
qao no palisi tiamadjo, venay itjen toa tjinocaoan.
S.TRANSL: When they perform rites, we give gifts for the spirits.

S.FORM: vaqu a sipatjutsautsau.
vaqo a sipatjocaocao.
S.TRANSL: Millet is the gift for summoning spirits to human beings(?).

S.FORM: nu neka, paisu anga, lami anga a zuma.
no neka, paiso anga, lami anga a zoma.
S.TRANSL: If we haven’t any, then money or some other staple food.

S.FORM: saka izua uta a sinikipapuluqem a sinitjuap a sinikipuvatjułayan a tja pinakitjukuda nu venay itjen.
saka izoa ota a sinikipapoloqem a sinitjoap a sinikipovatjoljayan a tja pinakitjokoda no venay itjen.
S.TRANSL: And we also differentiate between gifts for success, for summoning spirits, for charms(?).

S.FORM: nu selapay aravats tja sitsułu tua qatsang.
no selapay aravac tja sicoljo toa qacang.
S.TRANSL: If it’s a very serious case we kill a pig.

S.FORM: nu tsemułu izua za zinatjak aya a sinipatjavang tua tsemas.
no cemoljo izoa za zinatjak aya a sinipatjavang toa cemas.
S.TRANSL: When we kill it, part is ‘set aside’ as an offering to the gods (to be eaten only by the immediate family).

S.FORM: azua zuma nu vutjułan mana ika makudanga a kanen nua mareka kaka.
azoa zoma no votjoljan mana ika makodanga a kanen noa mareka kaka.
S.TRANSL: The rest of the meat can be eaten by the relations.

S.FORM: aitsu a qemazał tjara kitsułu sakamaya.
aico a qemazalj tjara kicoljo sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: When there is a haunting(?) we certainly join in a sacrificial feast.

S.FORM: azua malada nu izua a naminvalak, sualapan tua mareka qatsiłay tua mareka valiseqał tua mareka qidung.
azoa malada no izoa a naminvalak, soalapan toa mareka qaciljay toa mareka valiseqalj toa mareka qidong.
S.TRANSL: When someone has a swelling the shaman removes it with stones, wood-chips or charcoal.

S.FORM: nu izua piqay, nu naminvalak a tja kinatsavatsavan, malaing anga a nasema varung tjayamadju tua siqaqivu.
no izoa piqay, no naminvalak a tja kinacavacavan, malaing anga a nasema varong tjayamadjo toa siqaqivo.
S.TRANSL: If we have sores or swellings on our bodies, the shamans say whatever comes to their minds to explain it.

S.FORM: vinułuq aya.
vinoljoq aya.
S.TRANSL: We are told that spirits have thrown something at us,

S.FORM: djinukul aya.
djinokol aya.
S.TRANSL: have hit us,

S.FORM: sinizurung sun aya.
sinizorong son aya.
S.TRANSL: have pushed us,

S.FORM: nasetsevung sun ayain itjen.
nasecevong son ayain itjen.
S.TRANSL: or we have met a spirit.

S.FORM: aitsu a malada makaya djemauł tua tja tjaisangas sa tja kiqaqivuan.
aico a malada makaya djemaolj toa tja tjaisangas sa tja kiqaqivoan.
S.TRANSL: Shamans can summon our ancestors so that we can converse with them.

S.FORM: nu izua a tja sikivadavadaq, paruqu itjen tua zaqu.
no izoa a tja sikivadavadaq, paroqo itjen toa zaqo.
S.TRANSL: If we have a question we put a crystal bead (on a gourd).

S.FORM: nu sitseker, łemaui aya.
no siceker, ljemaoi aya.
S.TRANSL: If it stays on, the answer is Yes.

S.FORM: izua i tjarivavaw a umaq nua tsemas.
izoa i tjarivavaw a omaq noa cemas.
S.TRANSL: The gods live in heaven.

S.FORM: nu ini anan ka patjełuin inika makaya a tjumaq i tjarivavaw.
no ini anan ka patjeljoin inika makaya a tjomaq i tjarivavaw.
S.TRANSL: If a shaman hasn’t yet qualified she can’t get into heaven.

S.FORM: qau nu tjumaq i tjarivavaw, ventjek azua malada.
qao no tjomaq i tjarivavaw, ventjek azoa malada.
S.TRANSL: When a shaman is going to enter heaven, she performs a rite of breaking bamboo.

S.FORM: nu uri malada tiamadju mesuaw a gemdeged sana pangtjengtjezi, sana sane djaladjalan.
no ori malada tiamadjo mesoaw a gemdeged sana pangtjengtjezi, sana sane djaladjalan.
S.TRANSL: When shamans are going to perform a trance rite, they yawn repeatedly and then the spirits come on them, and they make their way (to heaven).

S.FORM: nu qematsuvung seman djalan uta sana patjezua.
no qemacovong seman djalan ota sana patjezoa.
S.TRANSL: When they have finished they make a way back and that’s the end.

S.FORM: nu makakivaqu pakasalut tua tsemas; nu makakiłumay uta.
no makakivaqo pakasalot toa cemas; no makakiljomay ota.
S.TRANSL: When we have finished harvesting millet we make a feast for the gods, and also when we have finished harvesting barnyard millet.

S.FORM: azua zuma nu maladan palisi a tjemamaku, palisi a keman tua paday tua masikau.
azoa zoma no maladan palisi a tjemamako, palisi a keman toa paday toa masikao.
S.TRANSL: For some shamans smoking is taboo, and also eating rice and wine from the plains(?).

S.FORM: łakua inika palisi a zuma.
ljakoa inika palisi a zoma.
S.TRANSL: But for some there is no such taboo.

S.FORM: nu sangasangasan vayan tua zaqu a mapułat.
no sangasangasan vayan toa zaqo a mapoljat.
S.TRANSL: When shamans begin they are all given a crystal bead.

S.FORM: łakua neka nu patsutsunan niamadju a tsemas.
ljakoa neka no pacoconan niamadjo a cemas.
S.TRANSL: But they don’t really see gods.

S.FORM: łakua tiamadju a kinemnemnem tua kakudan niamadju.
ljakoa tiamadjo a kinemnemnem toa kakodan niamadjo.
S.TRANSL: It’s they themselves who think up their customs.
